label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, March 8, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, thanking her for sending the items he had requested, advising her on taxes and business affairs of Medway Plantation, and advising her on how to best join him in Hawaii.

March 8, 1943
Hello Sweet,
Monday morning and raining. Can any combination be
better. Yesterday was overcast and there were no waves so we
could not surf, but I feel I can not complin after my wonderful week
at the shooting school.
You have asked me whether I ever received The United
State News. I get it regularly and both Morris fnd I think it is
better in many respect than Time. I also received Oeschener 
bohk and we have both read and liked it a great deal. At present 
another man in the office is reading it but has not told,me what 
-he thought. I also received the tennis balls but am certain that 
I told you so in a previous letter, it will probably arrive when the
war is over. 
I would certainlyraise Sams wages ten dollars as he
is tho only thing between the skies and Medway. By that I mean
the roof would leak and the windows wou d fall out andthe sheds
would collapse if he left. He is invaluable, more so than Miss
Finucan because youcould always have the firm in New York keep your
books but nothing will hold that old place together except a carpenter
and electrician working hand in handwihth God.
I do not understand Ericson saying that as you were not.
living in South Carolina you will not have to pay taxes. First
You have to be a resident of some state and you cannot claim
maryland as you own property in South Ghrolina and lived there for
five months of this year. Secondly South Carolina will look
with suspicion on your changing your residence so quickly after only
,half a year add you will undoubtly have trouble with them. Thirdly
what state does he want-you pg pay taxes in, probably New York so it
will be easier for him as he knows what the New York laws are;
persgnaly I would not chanfe as I do not see any advantage  o doing
so. We know how difficult New York State has always been wath you
and the trouble they have given us and unless there is a decided
advantage being a citizen of scme other state I would stay in
South Carolina until we decide where wo wish to live.
Undobtly you will receive this letter after youhave
returned from Medway and needless to ssy_I sm crazy to hear how you
liked your trip there,whether you were bored with tfe place and still
had that frustrated feeling or whether time and experience in
Washington made you look upon it with a less critical eye. I
suppose Rose is now a complete wreck and can do little more than e
crawl on hands end kness wbout the pl ce after coping with all the
nigresses and their stupidity; I do hope you had wonderful weather
and that nothing marred the Field Marshalls visit. It can be
a lovely place as long as the water runs and the lights work,
and it can be terrible when evertyning including the servants
[End Page 1]
become tempremental. After living there for a while it reminds me
of the women who was beating the drum in a salvation army band. 
After finishing s tune the leader stepped forward and said we will
now have a few words from sister Sue. Sister Sue stpeeped forward
and said "before joing the salvation Army I use to smoke, I use to
drink, at least a quart a day flowed down my gullet, I use to
sin." She paused dramatically and then finished now that I am in
the salvation army I don't do a dam thing but beat this lousy
serum a1Lday. Medway is very much like that , when away we do
a xxxxxxxhxxxx million thing[s], but afterbeing there for a month
one does nothing but worry. 
Have you heard anything more about being able tocome out
here. I do hope it omes through, but want to warn you that you
will not have to xxxx know my apartment address because you will
arive so quickly. Unless you are an Admiral you will go to
San Francisco and w ait there for transportation about two weeks,
then you will be put on a ten day covoy ship and will arrive here
just one month after leaving Washington. The aeroplanes ase so crow
ded that you will not have a chance of ogetting on one, commanders
and even captains have been unable to obtain nasseage so I do not
tuink your chances are so good. Lets hope for the best however.
Goodbue sweetheart, with all my love
Sidney
[End Page 2]
